reviews: \nI guess someone thought they could get more revenue by playing ads while listening to your Amazon music Playlist that only contains purchased music. What's the point in buying music from Amazon music only to have to listen to ads still. Avoid this product if you want to use it as a speaker to listen to purchased music.\n

titles: Ready to hit this with a hockey stick!
reviews: \nI\u2019m at my last nerve with these things. We have 6. Including echo shows. Every single one can\u2019t hear. Supposed to be so advanced and can\u2019t even offer simple features.\n

reviews: \nAlexa seems to be getting worse and worse at voice recognition. Half the time we can't get the Fire TV to pause using Alexa and it's all but useless for searching things. That's literally just after using Alexa to turn the device on. We used to use Alexa a good bit, but we've all but given up most of the time. The only thing the Echo has going for it is good sound. That's not all that useful if you can't get Alexa to recognize what you're wanting it to do though. We use our Google Home Mini speakers far more often now.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on February 2, 2020
titles: Cheap, economical, but not as good as HomePod to understand me across the noisy room
reviews: \nAs a cheap entry to voice-control, this is fine; it\u2019s not going to hear a command across a noisy room like HomePod will, and it can\u2019t keep a half-dozen voices separate to avoid your child shouting \u201cbaby shark\u201d from corrupting your \u201cturn down volume\u201d command.  I find anything over half volume, I\u2019m standing inches from it screaming to get the command recognized \u2014 so it doesn\u2019t seem to noise-cancel itself from the audio input.  ..so it\u2019s no HomePod, and can make all voice-assistants seem crappy, but if mediocre is Ok (and you don\u2019t care about privacy) then this is fine.I\u2019m going to upscale to the HomePod: I\u2019m a bit tired of the words spoken into this device showing up as suggested things to buy, when it actually understands me.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on January 27, 2020
reviews: \nWhen I set up this device it was straight forward and I had no issues. A few months after the initial set up the Echo would lose the signal. Researched what could cause this, I checked my internet Signal strength, purchased a wifi extender. Contacted Amazon and performed their suggested troubleshooting. Frustrated and disappointed I left the device gather dust. The rep never suggested I return it for a replacement. The holidays and birthdays around the corner I had more important things to be concerned with. I attempted to set up the echo dot once and for all, in a new location closer to the wifi signal. Finally threw the towel in because this now seemed like a faulty device. Contacted customer service for a 2nd time and after 28 minutes and having my call escalated to a Lead because I refused a 15% discount off of the purchase of a new device. The original purchase amount was refunded. So I should be satisfied, to a point. I spent 30 minutes troubleshooting to no avail during my 1st call, 2nd call lasted 28 minutes more. Customer service should not take 2 calls and an hour for a return of $26.49.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on January 5, 2020
titles: Not good enough to buy, not awful enough to throw out.
reviews: \nI wouldn't buy this, it came "free" as part of a deal with security cameras and couldn't be unbundled.  I figured it would make a good additonal portable speaker even though I wouldn't compromise my privacy by using Alexa and I am not lazy so can still use switches, appliances or keyboards instead of repeatedly screaming clarifying commands at a box. First, it doesn't use a usb plug and the base of the plug is so big it blocks the other receptacles on outlets. It is also heavy and falls out. There is no power button, so you must unplug it to turn it off. You will want to turn it off as it emits a big lit ring that is bright enough to bother you at night. Lastly, the sound quality is mediocre.\n

titles: Needs to step the sound quality waaay up!!:(
reviews: \nVoice Recognition, integration all that was fine however, the sound quality sounds like those old 1970\u2019s clock radio speakers. The sound quality is so poor Especially when you turn up the volume it seems to get worse. It\u2019s to the point where you almost had enough to turn it down so it could sound halfway decent. Amazon, do whatever you need to do the step that part up because it\u2019s strong enough for an Adult but, more suitable for an infant in his or her room and you want to play them a lullaby that doesn\u2019t get too loud that\u2019s just enough power to put that child to sleep....that\u2019s what the dot is to me.....\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on October 22, 2020
reviews: \nI had a google speaker that was super helpful, but when I saw that Echo Dots were on sale, I bought 3. I went ALL in. Got them, hooked them up, downloaded the app and the issues began. I bought my mother a speaker for the AUX capability - never worked. Looking online you can deregister the speaker 3x and try it again but it has yet to work. My son has a blast with his, asking it stupid questions, but the Spotify app is spotty. You can't control it from Alexa and Alex doesn't always recognize what is being asked. He asks for a specific kid friendly pod cast, specifies the name of the show and says "podcast" after it, but it plays some raucous trap music that while I respect, isn't good for a child to hear.The only perks have been routines and keeping kids occupied. The speakers functionality is better suited for kids. I'm sending mine back and I may go back to google or anker has some amazing wireless speakers.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on December 7, 2019
reviews: \nWish I could have used this thing, but after spending over 2 freaking hours with Amazon Kindle/Echo Techs on the phone trying to simply connect it to my WiFi signal through my iPhone, which I note has not had a single problem since I moved into this apartment in July 2019, I got pissed and gave up and realized that it had been a big waste of time and inconvenience to try and set up a cheap $24 plastic spy toy that I will probably rarely use.I called Comcast Xfinity 3 times, had a technician come out and they said they could not figure out why my WiFi connection got thrown off except that it might have been because of the attempt to connect to the Echo Dot. So frustrating!The kicker? I had my father take this Echo Dot to his home and try it and you know what? It worked just fine. He also has Comcast Xfinity, except he has an Android and I have an iPhone.Moral of the story- Comcast and iPhone? Move cautiously. I used to think Amazon could do no wrong, now I think twice.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on May 18, 2020
titles: Some units don't meet quality standards
reviews: \nI was super psyched up to receive the Echo Dot, I got a great deal on it and wanted it to compete head-to-head with my Google Home setup. However, from the first moment forward I had nothing but trouble.First, you cannot assign a static IP to the Echo Dot. This meant I had to add an additional lease in my router for it to connect. Then, once I got it up and running, it would wake up with the wake word, but listen and listen, and never respond to what I say. Amazon admitted that it was a bug with that specific device, and I was sent a replacement. However, when the replacement arrived, it has an internal power failure and could never actually boot. Which put me in a stuck situation, because I already used my warranty service on the first one, even though I have two duds. The reason I gave sound quality 4 stars is I can cast music and audio to the Dot, I just can't talk to it.Long story short, I'm sure the device is great, but quality control failed me twice in a row.\n

titles: Alexa sucks. Go with Google instead.
reviews: \nWhere to start? It's unintuitive & does virtually nothing helpful outside of give the forecast, it talks to us when we've said nothing resembling "Alexa", and despite opting for the say-less option in the app, this stupid thing still adds "By the way, ____" half the time after one simple command, even when I WHISPER. Alexa. People are sleeping. I do not want to learn your other features when you're not good at the ones you're supposed to be.At best, it's a timer that may or may not work. At worst it's a privacy invading, inferior product and it's been created just for our smoothbrained generation who's so quickly welcomed an exchange of their privacy for instant gratification.\n

reviews: \nI love the echo's capability to network with all other Alexa/Echo devices. It is fun to utilize. My only gripe is the sound quality. Which leads me to believe their security whether is actually decent enough. Compared to Google home, maybe twice in the 2 years I've had it.I've heard some of those mystery sounds like the train but never on the speaker I'm currently listening in to. People talk about notifications but you're able to turn that off,, but they dont give you a time frame. I wish I could return it but I already threw out the box. \U0001f62d\n

reviews: \nI dont understand what this product is actually designed to do. Is it a speaker? Technically yes, it is a speaker. But the sound of this speaker is so unlistenable I would never listen to music on it. Extremely grating harsh highs and the muddiest of lows even at low volumes. Otherwise I guess I could ask Alexa to do things. I dont understand why I'd do this with a phone in my hand. One swipe and I have a search engine at my fingertips. This is much easier than waiting for Alexa to find me useful information audibly with no screen to scan for what I need. In the end I'm totally confused as to what this things function is actually supposed to be.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on January 7, 2021
titles: Adults didn't want it, kids couldn't use it
reviews: \nThe device itself is what it should be, but the only person in our house who wants Amazon listening to every word you say is our child, to whom the novelty is more important than her privacy. After agreeing to a bunch of security and privacy contracts, I had to set the Dot up through my account. It can't just be used as a standalone smart speaker, so everything you do with it is linked to your Amazon account. When my child asked it to play music, it started playing a Punk Rock Channel. I set up a family account to try to fix it, but it then tells you that Echo isn't available on children's accounts. Waste of time and money, signed over more privacy to Amazon, and overall useless for what we wanted it for. We unplugged it within 10 minutes because of the account issues and my child kept getting creeped out when the speaker would activate without saying "hey Alexa."\n

reviews: \nWe have echo dots in 3 rooms.  Now that my kids does distant learning, I program reminders into Alexa to remind them when their next zoom lesson starts.  Don't get me wrong, they can tell time...Alexa helps to keep them on task.  My only problem is that they recently updated the reminder and it has become more cumbersome to use.  I use to be able  customize my reminder so that it's every Mon/Wed/Fri.  Now I have to set them all individually.  Also, I use to be able to select multiple devices I want the notification to remind on.  Now, I can only select one or all, I would need to cancel the whole reminder and start over again.  It would be so much better if the reminder feature was more flexible to let me change which devices I want the reminder to announce on and also be able to select multiple days for the same reminder.  If it does not work itself out, I might try something different.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on March 17, 2020
titles: Extremely complicated, multiple sources of directions, impossible for me
reviews: \nI purchased my Dot during the holiday sales to use as a radio.  I first spent an hour or two in January during which I consulted the enclosed directions, downloaded the app to my KIndle Fire, and tried to keep going.  Google search gave me a website for help.  Phone help took control of my computer, sold me new security software (for 4X what I paid for the Dot), and finally got me connected to Alexa.  Alexa could find NPR, but she couldn't find any other station using the call letters.  By the way, the only way to turn off the Dot is unplug it.  Now it's two months later.  On my end table are the dot, my smart phone, and my Fire.  The Dot announced it was connected 20 minutes ago and would let me know when she was ready.  I'm using the time to let you know the Dot is not for technical amateurs.  Now I'll go back to watching the Orange light go around.  Frankly, I like the blue and green better.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on April 21, 2021
titles: Used to be good, now daily ads
reviews: \nFor whatever reason, giant companies think the best thing that they can do that customers will love is throw in advertisements while asking simple things like "alexa, what time is it?" She will answer and now she will say "by the way" and suggest ways you can give amazon more money. Unplugged. Over it. My blink camera also now requires a subscription service to store videos, out of nowhere. These companies can afford to give things out for cheap and promise to be the good guys, crushing their competition, and then once it's safely dominated, ruin the user experience by making it exactly what nobody wants. And what can we do, we already have these devices and are now at the mercy of the mega company that will suck the life and enjoyment out of all the technology we grew to love.\n

reviews: \nI love the echo and wanted to take advantage of the Prime Day deal to add the service to more rooms. I contacted support and was told because I ordered two echo dot's in the past, one in June and One in August, which I ordered without any promo code, I could not use the 2 for 1 Prime day promo code. I was then told everything is automatic in the system so I was out of luck, support could not assist, even though the offer never said anything about a first time purchase or new customer - just that it only applied to Prime members. reviews: \nSince Audible is an Amazon company, I don\u2019t see why it is so darn difficult to play Audible books on my Echo dots. If I miss a bit and want to rewind a few seconds, it practically takes an act of Congress, a dispensation from the Pope, and a team of twenty mules to manage it.  Most of the time, I have to disable the app completely, find the place I want on the Audible app, and then re-start Alexa, and even then, it only works about half the time.  I\u2019m about to give up on it.Additionally, my routines, which I have created to help manage my time, do not consistently work.  I never know whether it\u2019ll work or not.I don\u2019t know what good the actual dot does if the app won\u2019t function properly. reviews: \nAmazon really knows how to screw a good thing up. Older version seems to work fine next generation is just awful. I have to ask it multiple times to do the simplest tasks like play music. I asked for news it gets me whether I asked for whether it plays music I will ask you the same question five times and it will do four different things. Absolute garbage! Edit: did you know that if you leave a bad review for an Amazon product they start blowing up your phone at work and spamming you with unsolicited calls? Loose my number idiots! You made a crap product stop trying to put that on me! Horrible experience with the Amazon tablet as well. Same thing happened, I try to return it and they just make it so difficult and spam you all week. They act like it's operator error, but it is their products that are deficient.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on November 5, 2021
titles: It's useful. However, it's created to be illogical!
reviews: \nI find setting a quick timer useful, but the awful sound that it makes to notify me of the timer completion, needs to have an option to altered in the alexa app. It does not have that option. That is the first illogical point, since the alarm sound has that option. The second illogical point is that the alarm and timer share the same volume setting, but not the same sound choice. That it's certainty the third illogical point. The fourth illogical point applies to both the alarm and timer. Three is no automatic cessation of around after a certain number of repetitions. That is desperately needed. When Amazon improves these features, I can rate the device higher.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on July 6, 2020
reviews: \nIn order for this system to work to its full potential, you are required to purchase a myriad of extraneous equipment, expensive equipment.  If you need help telling time, a weather update, or some bad jokes, she's fine by herself.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on July 7, 2021
reviews: \nI made the mistake of standardizing on echo devices. And my family regrets it. Aside from all the privacy concerns that are reasonable, with each new iteration the echoes become worse. They are cluttered with capabilities you will never use which makes the basic uses \u2013 sleep noise, music, weather, and other simple tasks - buried under a mountain of garbage.Yes, the early morning notifications are tedious. Yes, the 10-word responses are tedious. Yes, Amazon Sidewalk is an invasion.But these devices fail at their basic reason for being: playing music. They are unpredictable, buggy, and incapable of simple commands - often commands that worked as recently as last week.Look elsewhere. Ask Alexa what is the best speaker on the market. She will tell you Sonos. Heed her this once.\n

reviews: \nAfter having several echo dot speakers for about a month, I must say that I find them both handy and annoying. This makes them terrible for bedrooms if you want to get any sleep. Also, if you have children be warned that your children will find it hilarious to turn on Alexa's burping skill or to tell her that they farted so that she will tell them "Congratulations!" Yeah, that's super annoying as a mom.\n

reviews: \nI got this with the special offer they were having for 99c. I figured I could try it out before buying more. The only thing that it has been useful for is the alarm. Even that though only has so many selections for the sound. I was excited about the celebrity alarm but then there wasn't any that I even would have used. I thought maybe there would be celebrities like Matthew McConaughey, Jennifer Anniston, so forth. The sound quality is great for such a little device when you can actually get the music to play. I am still learning how to configure it. That can be a good thing or not. Good because it gives you a little bit of a challenge but then at the same time I could miss out on some cool setting or skill. I am sure that I will have more later as I mess around with it.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on October 18, 2020
reviews: \nWe've enjoyed an Echo Dot for a few years and thought this would make a nice holiday gift for my wife's sister. When we got ours, it was a simple matter to pair the Echo Dot with our computer's Bluetooth. How things have changed! I suspect so that Amazon can enhance its data mining/privacy-violating capabilities. When I attempted to install our sister's Windows 10 laptop, the nightmare began. "Install the Alexa App," I was told. Of course, there is no App for a laptop. After a couple of hours of trying some sort of workaround, all failing, I deferred to another day. This weekend, I thought that I'd get assistance in what I thought must somehow be a simple installation (as ours had been); I sought Amazon's technical support's assistance. A couple of hours later, after being handed off in turn to a total of six "experts" none of whom could come up with any solution, I decided to return the device.  Ugh...\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on January 12, 2020

reviews: \nThis was a free promotional gift from another item I bought recently. My fire stick still has the issue and Alexa is back in the box where it belongs.  I have no intention of talking to my TV just to be asked another question by a machine that keeps repeating itself. After 45 minutes on two different occasions on the phone with Amazon support I was pissed off to no end dealing with this BS. The programming fire stick offers is great, I am a Prime member and really happy with what's offered with the fire stick . All I want is to be able to turn my TV on and off with tha button on the remote.  Stay away from the echo dot, it's not worth the trouble or it's eavesdropping capabilities. dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on October 10, 2020
reviews: \nTypically in tech, things improve with each new version. Sadly, the progression from 2nd gen to 3rd gen Alexa has resulted in a very muffled voice for Alexa. I can't stand it. It sounds like Alexa is activating from under a blanket. I'm surprised more people don't complain about this in the reviews. If you google about it, then you will find lots of amazon forums discussing the terrible sound quality.I have tweaked the Treble, Mid, and Low range EQ in the Alexa app. Cranking the treble and lowering the two bass settings did not provide a meaningful improvement in sound quality.I think they tried to make bass improvements from 2nd to 3rd but they did it at the expense of verbal audio quality.I have two of these 3rd gens and I plan to return them. I don't want to constantly strain to hear a muffled response from Alexa. I'd rather have 2nd gens.\n

If I have a tv with stereo why would I want to play music on this tiny speaker? Everything non amazon works flawless and was relatively easy to set up and use anything related to amazon is a nightmare and does not work properly via echo/Alexa. It\u2019s almost funny how everything else linked up and set up fine yet everything amazon sucks and won\u2019t link up right or work 100%.\n

titles: Unreliable... always a problem with the Hardware and Alexa!!!
reviews: \nUnreliable... always a problem with the Hardware and Alexa!!! I have deployed 2 of these lemons and they are nothing but one issue  after another. There are so many issues I don't know where to start... so here are a few... 1) Alexa often can't understand what I say (yes, I speak in the same voice tone and level); 2) One in the kitchen does not work sometimes; but the one in the bedroom does;  3) One or both of them are always disconnecting... my Phone never disconnects, my PC never disconnects, my TV never disconnects! 4) I have called Amazon Tech multiple times and had them fix things; but that does not last long.Hey Google... you out there... I'll trade you 5 Echo Dot 3's... for 3 of your devices!!! \U0001f60e\n

titles: WORTHLESS!!  PLEASE BUY SOMETHING ELSE!!!!!  DONT MAKE MY MISTAKE!!
reviews: \nWhile the overall utility of the Echo is good, Amazon uses it for unsolicited advertising.  This is very annoying.  Also, while Amazon's intentions are good, the notification feature can be an irritant too.  They will notify you of weather advisories, shipment details, or other things.  Echo lets you know by turning the light yellow.  The problem with this is that it can occur in the middle of the night and lights up the room.  Amazon needs to allow users to turn off the advertising and notification features of the Echo.\n

reviews: \nThe Echo Dot works as expected. However, after purchasing several to place around our house, I was informed the price for the Amazon unlimited music would increase. titles: It won't chime with my Ring doorbell
reviews: \nCan't get it to chime when my Ring doorbell is activated--the only reason we bought it. It pairs with it and says it's connected but when we test it, NOTHING!  We went through all the correct steps for notifications, etc.And when I try to get help using their app or website, it never submits my inquiry and doesn't tell me what's wrong with it. Super frustrating and I have boxed it back up.  I will likely remove the Ring doorbell, too since only I or my husband can hear the chime (we don't allow the kids to have smart phones).\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on December 26, 2019
titles: Not good for multiple users on same account
reviews: \nI have two children with dots, my wife and I each have a dot and we have a plus at a vacation home.  App only allows two accounts (Prime).  Teens and children can not have separate Echo accounts.  So all the devices connected to my account are limited.  For instance, only one device can play a different Spotify tune at a time.  So if I am playing a song and they want a different song, mine will turn off.  I can't use guard (the security system) on just the Echo at my vacation home.  I spent over three house with tech support and the only answer was to set up my kids with their own Prime account (that I have to pay monthly and they would lose access to our audible account).  I guess it works well if you want them all to do the same thing.  It also messed up audio button on my iPhone, for which tech had no idea how to fix.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on April 20, 2021
reviews: \nI loved this when I got it, but then Amazon decided to step in because I was using it too much to play my music.  I was working from home and was playing music, but about every 45 min to 1 hour it would shut off.  I thought it was broken.  Nope, Amazon is controlling  how long you can listen to your music.  If there is no activity, then the music shuts off.  What???  So they are monitoring it, according to Amazon (I called them).  I unplugged and put it away, along with my Echo.  I think Amazon owes me a partial refund for my membership and a refund for my devices.  DO NOT BUY THESE DEVICES UNLESS YOU WANT TO BE MONITORED.\n

reviews: \nI have 2 cochlear implants to let me hear again and I bought this Echo Dot because I thought it would connect to my phone (for calls) and would also help me hear music more clearly. I have tried and tried to complete setup but no matter what I do, whether I use my phone with the Alexa app or my computer, it will not connect to the Internet. It will connect to my computer... but will not connect to my phone. It will connect to the bluetooth on my phone but what use is that without connecting to Internet?I am very frustrated with this thing. And, it's not that I am technologically impaired. I am a retired computer tech so I believe I know how to follow instructions.I have a Firestick connected to my TV and everything works just fine. Why won't the Echo Dot connect?There is no point in me trying to call customer support.. my cochlear implants don't "hear" well with the cell phone.\n

titles: Disappointed  with the Amazon prime in numerous debts . Prime video, Prime fresh as well.
reviews: \nI've decided to return this Alexa. I've had too many problems with this from the get go. One of the main reasons I purchased this was to take it with me on business trips & vacation trips. reviews: \nI have 10 of these devices at my home and work. Initially, they are wonderful. I had no complaints until the speakers just started failing. They were working perfect, then the next morning, the speaker would light up like Alexa was responding but no sound came out. It is as if the speaker connection came loose in the device. You can tap on the bottom of the device and get it to make a sound, but it is like a static sound. No music plays. I contacted Amazon, and they told me that the devices come with a Limited warranty. They would credit my account for 15% off a new device. These devices are both about 6 months old. My others are still working good for now. I will still buy more of these, but am not happy about the longevity of the product at all.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on February 4, 2020
reviews: \nWe cannot get the Echo Dot to link with Apple Music. I've called Amazon Alexa help many times now and each representative requires that we trouble shoot the problem together "in real time." So each calls tend towards an hour of trying, again and again, to link Apple Music to the Dot. Each representative tells me that they cannot resolve the problem and promises to create a ticket and call me back. I've been calling and hearing this response for more than a month, but today's representative tells me that they can't find a ticket. That no one's created a ticket. They promise to create a ticket and call me back. We'll see.We purchased Apple Music specifically for this Echo Dot, and we've not been able to use the first month of the subscription. And I've logged hours in phone calls with Amazon Alexa helpful. I'm an Amazon fan, so I'm very disappointed in this customer service, which is the worst I've ever experienced.\n

titles: So disappointed, guys. I can\u2019t believe this device has all these great reviews.
reviews: \nWe have several second generation echo dots and we really enjoy them. We use them all the time, so much so that I wanted Alexa in every room. When I saw the Black Friday deals for the third generation echo dot, I snatched up four of them. I was super excited because of the great reviews and that these were supposed to have better sound quality than the second generation echo dot. Boy am I disappointed. The sound quality is really horrible. Alexa sounds like she\u2019s trying to talk to you while being smothered by a pillow. It\u2019s that bad. All four sound this way, so I know that I didn\u2019t just get a bad one. They\u2019re all bad. Music sounds a little better and the news update sounds a little better than Alexa, but everything still sounds a bit muffled. It\u2019s how Alexa sounds that is the absolute worst. Very disappointing because we talk to her all the time. Fix this, Amazon!\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on July 8, 2020
reviews: \nStick with the Google Home - so much more intuitive and functional. Especially if you want it to use it to search for anything on the web, such as answering questions. Or to integrate it with other smart technology throughout your home. It's constantly making errors, unable to find the information we're looking for or just not working and giving us the Alexa version of the spinning color wheel. We received this with our Ring security system, which in theory would be great together, but in reality, it can't do even simple things you would expect from a smart home security system. For example, we want to use it in to control the light on our outdoor motion camera when we're outside at night, but it isn't capable. Amazon needs to do a serious upgrade of its software technology on the Echo dot, and they need to partner with Google so they can actually use their web search engine.\n

titles: Sounds good, but doesn\u2019t pick up my voice.
reviews: \nAugust 2021 Update: The aux input option is no longer available or functioning.Original: This is a great generation SPEAKER and is easy to connect to from my phone or with an AUX cable (guests). This is not a great smart assistant as it doesn\u2019t recognize my voice, it can\u2019t hear me most of the time, doesn\u2019t respond, and it doesn\u2019t have answers to most of my inquiries. It\u2019s good when I\u2019m >3 feet away from it. Because of this I only use it as a voice input for home automation or as a speaker in the kitchen when I\u2019m cooking.Yes, I\u2019ve followed the voice recognition setup and I\u2019ve tried resetting it as well as cleared past voice inputs. It\u2019s just not great at recognizing my voice. Others have absolutely no problem with it though. I gave up on this and started using a different brand\u2019s voice input device and speaker along side this.\n

The good thing is that on the right surface it vibrates through and feels louder. Maybe I'll sell it or give it away.\n

titles: Small size and good sound quality.
reviews: \nThese are some of the most unreliable electronic devices that I've ever owned... I've had nothing but problems with them since the beginning. They are constantly having connection issues when we a strong internet signal through out the house.I purchased 5 of them and have problems with every single one of them. I thought by resetting them and starting over would eliminate the problems but now... they won't even reconnect to anything. So in the trash they all go.I'd buy ANYTHING else other than Alexa if you want your stuff to actually work.\n

The music is way more frustrating. Get this - on Apple Music, there is no way to shuffle the music. Imagine how annoying it is to constantly play the same playlist from your Apple Music and have to listen to it in the same sequence every time! No option to shuffle!! dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on July 5, 2020
titles: Don't Purchase If You Have Hearing Problems
reviews: \nI love the idea of Alexa and the things I can do on voice command, such as play music. The reason for the one star is I cannot understand her if I ask more than a simple question such as "What's the temperature?" She has a soft voice and her rate of speech is too rapid for me and my hearing problems. I tried to play Jeopardy today and although I could hear and understand Alex Trebek (if that is him) without a problem, I couldn't understand when Alexa spoke so I couldn't play. I've hooked her up to a high quality speaker I have, but it's not the volume level, it's her voice tone and rate of speech. I don't recommend this product if you have trouble understanding soft voices. I think if the voice of Alexa was more like Alex Trebek voice that I could understand, I would give it 5 stars.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on November 10, 2019
titles: Alexa will not play the same versions of songs on my Apple/ITunes Playlists
reviews: \nThe Echo needs a little work. The sound quality tends to be a little bass heavy. Also, you have to say things to Alexa very precise or your request is not understood (one dimensional). However, those are things I can get used to. What I CANNOT get used to is Alexa not playing the same versions of songs I have on my Apple/ITunes playlist. I cannot tell you how disconcerting it was to have Alexa play my FAV's playlist, and instead of playing Mary J. Blige's Each Tear (solo), this awful male voice joins in for the second chorus.  The male voice sound so odd, I thought Alexa was possessed. I pulled out my MAC to check the version of song I had purchased years ago and it was correct, however, the song Alexa was/is playing is not my version of the song. So disappointed that this thing will not play my music.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on February 26, 2020
reviews: \nI purchased 2 Echo Dots for Christmas from Best Buy and one failed after 2 months of use, it wouldn't connect to my wifi, I called the support team and they lead me through multiple exercises before telling me to order another one and they would refund me and send me a return label. I never heard from them after that so I called again and told them instead of the credit to just send me another Echo Dot. The catch was if I wanted it sent to me immediately I would have to pay $15 for the replacement or send in the defective one and wait until they diagnosed the problem and fixed it or they would send me a replacement. I'm unhappy I had to pay $15 dollars because I wanted the replacement immediately, I paid for the Echo Dot in December so why couldn't Amazon take responsibility and replace it for free!!\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on November 12, 2020
titles: Could be perfect, except for ONE thing
reviews: \nThere's really only one feature that made me go from 5 stars to 1.  Turning the notification option on is great because when you get a package delivered, your Echo will chime at you and light up yellow.  You then ask Alexa what the notification is and she tells you "a shipment has arrived".  Awesome.  HOWEVER, at random times, the Echo will chime and light up yellow.  So you ask Alexa what the notification is AND IT'S TO TELL ME SOMETHING IS ON SALE??!!  TO BUY BUY BUY MORE..  Really??  We get telemarketing-like-calls through our smart devices that we paid for?  On top of paying $120 every year for a membership, you've got to advertise out loud in our own personal homes?  How much money do you need??\n

reviews: \nWith this 3rd generation Echo Amazon is trying to compete with other whole house music systems (think Sonos), and it's definitely better than the prior generation in this regard. For voice only I find the 3rd gen Echo to be unacceptably boomy and near unintelligible for every day use like voicing instructions, news, weather, etc. Glad I kept my other four 2nd gen devices. Can totally understand them, even being of slightly bad hearing.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on December 16, 2019
reviews: \nI originally had an Echo, 1 gen. Coming home one day it was connected to WiFi. I spoke to 3 reps. Followed all instructions it would not connect. Then an Echo dot was sent & it too would not connect, 2 reps that day & was told that something in the WiFi might have changed. Had my cable remotely reboot WiFi. Didn\u2019t help. I then was told to try another Dot. Did yesterday and needless to say it had the same problem. Both are being returned. To check my WiFi, I disconnected my IPad & reconnected it with no problems. I live in a condo community & my service is with Comcast. One of neighbors purchased a Dot , my recommendation & since we use same provider, I asked her & she has had no problems.I don\u2019t have any idea why It didn\u2019t work but will miss it.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on August 24, 2020
titles: Alex's Voice is Too Muffled and Extremely Hard to Hear - Gen 3 Echo Dot
reviews: \nWhile the music audio is acceptable after adjusting the equalizer, Alexa's voice is absolutely horrible! Equalizer adjustments cannot be made to Alexa's voice, only to music. Alexa sounds like she's speaking through a thick pillow and it's nearly impossible to distinguish muffled sounds apart from each other. This unit replaced a Google Home Mini which was a HUGE mistake! The voice on the Google Mini is heads and shoulders above the Echo Dot (Gen 3). From other reviews about the Gen 3, this is a widely broadcast complaint and has yet to be addressed by Amazon. Not sure if this is a speaker or firmware issue since the music quality is better than Alexa's voice. Not sure why Alexa's voice can't be adjusted with an equalizer. This new product is a clear failure and needs to be recalled or addressed with a firmware upgrade!\n

reviews: \nThis is my second echo, I love the product but I got a broken one this time and tried to do a simple return like i've done before. dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on August 6, 2020
titles: Stay away! 90 day warranty and fails shortly after....
reviews: \nPurchased this item from a retail store near my home. As it turns out, the 90 day warranty was only a couple of months out of date when this unit decided to completely fail and become a $50 paper weight. Without wifi connectivity, this unit is completely unusable and the best that Amazon is willing to do is offer a 15% discount on a future Echo device purchase. Save your money and get something else from a company that stands behind their products with more than a 90 day bogus warranty. Interestingly, the representative also kept insisting that it was because I purchased this from a retail location - almost as if they use different quality components when purchasing from Amazon.com versus a big box store. I will not be purchasing another Amazon device because clearly you get less than what you pay for.\n

reviews: \nI got the Echo Dot for $20 and thought it was a real bargain until I tried to use it. I guess I was expecting too much and should have spent more money on a bigger one or something. Everytime I ask for it to play one of my playlists it tells me it can't and tells me I might like some random radio station it starts playing. dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on October 2, 2020
titles: Glad I found out how much money Amazon was fixing to steal from me before it was too late
reviews: \nI am 71 years old, retired and currently recovering from spinal surgery. I have always loved just kicking back listening to old rock. Saw this Amazon music thing and thought it might be nice. Then everything started to unwind and I saw the actual charges. So even though it is just me here, having a smart phone, a notebook and a desk top with the Amazon Music app installed, gives Amazon the right to charge me close to $100 a month??? I don't think so. Sweet Amazon that admittedly does fill some time and voids in time does not indicate they aren't willing to jump right in and help drain your life savings oh so quickly. Hopefully if I can just open one person's eyes to this which will allow me to sleep a little better tonight.\n

reviews: \nThis device will not work without the Amazon Alexa app specifically. Unless you have a phone that can work that app(Anything made in China will, anything made outside of China you're probably SoL) then this device will not work. On top of that, it is completely impossible to turn off voice data gathering, the moment this device is in your home and connected every word you say is getting logged. This is doubly bad considering Amazon does a lot of business in certain countries where it is the legal mandate to share that information with the government. So this device A, does not work unless you already have specific devices, and it does not tell you this... B, collects information about you with no way to turn it off.... C, gives that information to governments.I wish there was a star below 1.\n

titles: Software will not update, I received two new units that have this issue.
reviews: \nSoftware version ending in _4900 will not update to latest version _6436. Tech support tried all known manual procedures to force update, still will not update. First was told had to RMA units for repair which is unsat for a brand new DOT 3. Once they were told that was not acceptable they offered to send new DOT 3's but would take two weeks for that also. Did not like RMA option because unit would be in repair mode for who know's how long. Two weeks to wait for new DOTs was not acceptable either.\n

reviews: \nThe speaker produces not close of the sound that you would hope for in a device of its size. Sounds like an average old AM radio... not full, dynamic or pleasing...\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on June 15, 2020
reviews: \nI have a 2nd Gen Echo Dot and have enjoyed it for some time. I bought a 3rd Gen Echo Dot to boost my multi-room capabilities.  I was disappointed to learn the following:1)This Echo Dot (3rd Gen) has a very muffled sound quality when Alexa is responding. This cannot be adjusted in the Alexa app and deeply impacts your ability to hear her responses.2) 2nd Gen and 3rd Gen Dots don\u2019t sync very well together; the only way to get music to play on both Echos at the same time is to use the Alexa App. If your system is set up to also stream Spotify, or other third party services, you will not have access to sync that music among your multi-Gen Echos.3) Credit where credit is due: the speakers are superior on the 3rd Gen.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on March 3, 2020
reviews: \nThe device stopped working after 100 days and only comes with a 90 warranty.  It will no longer connect to wifi it just stopped working.  I have contacted customer support and Alexa Support and they just say buy a new one.  They will no t replace the item outside the 90 days even though you return window in your account says product may be replaced up to a year from purchase date.  This statement is false and they will not offer you anything other than  %15 to buy a new one.  Why buy a new one when the chances are it will last 100 days no thanks.  Just thought that with as big as the company is and the advertisement they have, they  would do more for their customers but they don't.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on August 30, 2020
reviews: \nI wanted the Alexa because I had seen such great performance in my friends' homes. I purchased the Echo Dot as an entry-level into the Alexa experience. I am extremely disappointed. Note that my internet is at 40 gbps and I fully understand how to connect hardware to wifi. But my Echo Dot performs so sporadically it is essentially useless. One day it will work well, playing the stations or podcasts I enjoy, and the next day it will say it granted my wish to play something, yet remain silent. I've had to supplement poor performance with my phone to listen to NPR or play Spotify stations. When it works, it is great, however I don't have the patience for a moody piece of hardware that randomly decides to take some time off when I need it.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on November 1, 2020
titles: A Once-Great Product is Now An In-House Advertiser
reviews: \nBe forewarned: Alexa devices of all sorts have begun "recommending" and "suggesting" things to do and things to buy, 24/7.  For the items with screens, expect endless displays of "Try This..." and "Wouldn't you like..." suggestions.  They can't be turned off.  And even the "audio-only" devices now make "helpful" additions when you give commands.  Ask for the weather at 2am when you're drifting off to sleep... expect the weather as a response, yes, and then a monologue from your device suggesting other things to try and "helpful" other suggestions...  Amazon has gone over the top with its advertising straight into your ears and eyeballs, without any conceivable means to turn these "suggestions" off.  We can't/shouldn't be okay with this slow creep of advertising.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on November 30, 2020
titles: First time Alexa user, far behind Google IMHO
reviews: \nI got 2 Dots free with a promotion and was eager to try them out since I have ALWAYS used the Google Assistant.  I wanted to see how they measure up.  For me, even though Alexa was the breakout technology, I think Google Assistant has the upper hand here.  It would wake for no reason, give totally off the wall responses to questions I didn't ask, and didnt integrate with several smart devices in my house. I know that Google Assistant is guilty of all the same issues, but I think to a lesser extent.  I guess this is more a review of Alexa than of the Dot, but it's really just a speaker and it's fine in that regard.\n

titles: Phone to echo dot to tv apps not supported
reviews: \nI connected my Bose speakers to echo dot using 3.5mm jack but I cannot play the music on Bose while playing any app on my new samsung qled tv except playing a song on amazon supported apps like amazon music. This is disappointing. I was under an impression that if I connect echo dot to my phone via Bluetooth and then cast anything on my tv through my phone(example YouTube app), echo dot will help play the sound on Bose but that\u2019s not the case. Now I need to buy analog to digital converter and optical cable all costing me additional $60-70 !I got fooled when amazon suggested me to buy both tv and echo dot as a package when in reality they are not 100% compatible like in case explained above. To me echo dot buying was waste of money :(\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on January 23, 2020
titles: Worst bluetooth experience ever!!! First-time reviewer/Last time user.
reviews: \nI own three other devices that connect to my iPhone and computer seamlessly, with bluetooth technology. After downloading the Alexa app, and struggling to make what should be a simple connection for over one hour, I finally gave in and called customer service. According to the person I spoke to, the device has to be connected to a dedicated wifi network before allowing for a bluetooth connection. Mind you, it says this nowhere in the app, on the box, or the limited instructions supplied. Yes, it's hard for me to believe, too. Somehow the device is not capable of using the phone data plan to make this simple introduction, and needs a dedicated wifi network to move forward. FOR A BLUETOOTH CONNECTION!?! Forget about trying to use a public wifi network. Another hour of my life wasted on poor product design.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on November 22, 2020
reviews: \nWhat an amazing waste of $40!  This useless piece of garbage functions correctly, but has absolutely no use to me.  It sits in the kitchen and randomly says things when it mistakenly thinks I'm talking to it.  That's about it.  I can tell it to make reminders, or I could have saved $40 and bought a piece of paper, wrote down a reminder, and taped it to my refrigerator door.  I guess people think they need junk like this these days because even the act of turning on light switches or setting microwaves seems like an intimidating amount of work.  What a sad world we live in, and this device absolutely typifies that.  Completely useless.\n

reviews: \nI'm a prime member and have used an echo dot in my daughters nursery for years to play nigh time music and lullabies. titles: The hardware is good, but the software needs a lot of improvement.
reviews: \nI have submitted this review several times but Amazon keeps erasing it!  \U0001f612This was purchased as an upgrade for the first generation Alexa.  Overall, much better for the same cost.The sound quality and volume increased significantly,  but it has trouble when communicating with Bluetooth speakers.  It can send them from quiet to loud skipping the mid range of comfort.  Yes, the Bluetooth speaker works just fine with other devices.Also, it has trouble responding when you choose it\u2019s name to be Echo, but not with the other (pre-programmed) names.  I think it is because \u201cEcho\u201d is two syllables and the others are three.  I would really like it if I could choose its name, so that my conversations with I would be more fluid.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on July 31, 2020
reviews: \nI received this speaker for free when I signed up for Sirius XM, so luckily it didn't cost me anything.  It has poor muffled sound quality, and poor voice recognition.  About 50% of the time it plays the wrong thing, or tells me that something isn't available that I wasn't even asking for.  Siri on my iPhone works a lot better.  Maybe Amazon should work with Apple to develop a decent smart speaker.  Plus Amazon keeps sending me "notifications" all the time, which are just promotions for various Amazon products.  Kind of like what they do on Kindle, only more annoying.  I might use this speaker just for listening to talk shows on Sirius XM so that I can bypass using my computer while listening to them.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on October 21, 2020
reviews: \nThe sound is too muffled, even after brightening the treble EQ and reducing the bass/mids on the app. It\u2019s ok for listening to dull sounding music, but extremely hard to understand a response from Alexa\u2019s speaking voice. However, if you like listening to speakers buried in a 12\u2019 stack of wet bath towels or at the bottom of a fish tank, then this unit could be an excellent choice for you. But if you\u2019re expecting to hear a clear crisp understandable answer from Alexa after falling victim to a sudden memory lapse, this unit ain\u2019t gunna happen..consider a retired school teacher to follow you around with a dictionary, a thesauruses and a bullhorn. A much better choice, trust me..\n

Unplugged took hammer to it, threw it in the trash. iPhone gives me the option to shut Siri down and I can always turn my phone off and still get calls on the landline.It\u2019s just as easy to hit a button on a app to turn lights on or off. It\u2019s not hard to find 5 minutes to write a shopping list.Do yourself a favor and don\u2019t destroy your memory. Dial your friends and families phone numbers a few times a week. write your appointment down and remember to look at it daily. Just throw out Alexa, Siri and Google put. They do more damage than good.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on February 16, 2020
titles: If you have a hearing condition expect to feel discriminated.
reviews: \nWithout CC (Close Captions) Anyone with a hearing condition will feel the discrimination act from Amazon due to there is no feedback of any form that completes a two way communication. Even Siri has CC thru your phone display!, Alexa should have thislind of CC thru out the App on your phone.Shame on you Amazon! All Alexa compatible devices should include CC feedback thru the app, and not just the ones with build in display.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on December 4, 2019
titles: Spoken output sounds incredibly muffled, not clear at all :-/
reviews: \nSpoken output by Alexa sounds incredibly muffled and not clear at all :-/I have two 3rd gen echo dots and the sound quality definitely is muffled. I've reduced bass and increased treble, but the sound is very bass'y/low, as if someone's speaking from under a pillow. It's ok for music, but any spoken sounds (what's the temperature, play news, etc) doesn't come out clear. Voices lack clarity, and sound thick :-/Very disappointed. I'm hoping there will be a software fix, and if not, perhaps a recall/exchange for those units.It's foremost a speaker, and as such it is poor for voice output. I expect(ed) better from Amazon - esp since this is the 3rd generation of this product.\n

reviews: \nOverall it\u2019s a good product with one fatal flaw. When I turn on my phone, scroll by a video of Facebook or the web and other times, Alexa blares at full volume \u201cplaying from iPhone\u201d from whichever speaker I used last. You can imagine how this affects me and my family, especially if it is at midnight or 6 am. There is now way to turn off this \u201cfeature\u201d. Google it! It\u2019s such a big issue I\u2019m ready to abandon a $200 investment in echo and switch to google home. The only way around it is to either never use it as a Bluetooth speaker or disconnect every time you finish using, but that kinda defeats the purpose...\n

titles: Definitely the Most Aggravating Piece of Electronics I Own
reviews: \nThere is a feature called "Hunches", whereby Alexa, once she has answered your question, e.g. "What is the weather in ____?" will recommend something, uninvited.  It is SO annoying. With great effort, it can be turned off for a day or two, but then it reverts back to putting its two cents in every interaction.  It stops when you scream, "Alexa, shut the ____ up,"  but by then, you're already aggravated. A truly horrible feature. I'm going to throw mine in the garbage, after I've smashed it with a hammer.\n

titles: Doesn't work with existing 5 Echo network. OK as single unit
reviews: \nBased solely on the experience with this Echo, I'd declare the product a disaster and customer rip off. This addition to a system with 5 Echos is a disaster. It performs individually, but not with the system.  I even re-identified all other Echos in our house to create a new connectivity system.  It's OK if you want a voice-on-command clock, or radio, or reminder, or reminder about your pet's vet appointment. Otherwise, it is a technological deficiency. Buy one or two, be happy. Don't expect a home-wide  reliable system. It's a fish that has been out of water too long.\n

titles: There is such a thing as too much technology
reviews: \nI never even took it out of the box. I never really wanted this level of AI in my house. I don\u2019t care what they tell you. That thing is listening all the time. We still have one because my husband refused to give it up but it is shut in a room that is his only for music and most of the time it\u2019s unplugged which makes me happy. There is no need for this thing. It is one more expensive technological toy and we already have plenty of technological toys with this level of sophistication that will do everything this thing does. You do not need the Echo.\n

titles: Alexa Integration is very frustrating.....overall not worth the purchase
reviews: \nSpeaking to a loudspeaker may be interesting, like making use of it as an intercom and switching on and off smart lights, but it starts getting frustrating very quickly. Whenever it is connected to my computer it starts playing paused videos on any tabs in chrome out there. Even if you pause the video it supersedes your command and starts that video again. The only option is to disconnect from the computer, which defeats the purpose of a Bluetooth enabled smart speaker itself. Overall the experience is not so good as this product needs more polishing and refinement.\n

reviews:
The media could not be loaded.
                



\xa0Was wondering why the voice recognition on this unit was so unreliable, then I decided to listen to the voice recordings.  Static, buzz, hash and clicking on EVERY recording!  Yes, it seemed to decipher what I was saying during this recording but it didn't manage to actually execute the command, and that is unfortunately typical.  Barely a year old, past the return window so into the recycling bin it goes. :(
